STAT 557: Homework 3, Carson Sievert, 10/22/2012

Link to Questions

1.1

binY <- function(Y) {
    q3 <- quantile(Y, probs = 1:3 * 1/3)
    bin3 <- rep(0, length(Y))
    bin3[which(Y < q3[1])] <- q3[1]
    bin3[intersect(which(q3[1] < Y), which(Y < q3[2]))] <- q3[2]
    bin3[which(q3[2] < Y)] <- q3[3]
    q5 <- quantile(Y, probs = 1:5 * 1/5)
    bin5 <- rep(0, length(Y))
    bin5[which(Y < q5[1])] <- q5[1]
    bin5[intersect(which(q5[1] < Y), which(Y < q5[2]))] <- q5[2]
    bin5[intersect(which(q5[2] < Y), which(Y < q5[3]))] <- q5[3]
    bin5[intersect(which(q5[3] < Y), which(Y < q5[4]))] <- q5[4]
    bin5[which(q5[4] < Y)] <- q5[5]
    q7 <- quantile(Y, probs = 1:7 * 1/7)
    bin7 <- rep(0, length(Y))
    bin7[which(Y < q7[1])] <- q7[1]
    bin7[intersect(which(q7[1] < Y), which(Y < q7[2]))] <- q7[2]
    bin7[intersect(which(q7[2] < Y), which(Y < q7[3]))] <- q7[3]
    bin7[intersect(which(q7[3] < Y), which(Y < q7[4]))] <- q7[4]
    bin7[intersect(which(q7[4] < Y), which(Y < q7[5]))] <- q7[5]
    bin7[intersect(which(q7[5] < Y), which(Y < q7[6]))] <- q7[6]
    bin7[which(q7[6] < Y)] <- q7[7]
    return(data.frame(Y, bin3 = as.factor(bin3), bin5 = as.factor(bin5), bin7 = as.factor(bin7)))
}

n <- 200
a <- -1  #Choose anything I want?
b <- 5  #Choose anything I want?
eps <- rnorm(n)
X <- runif(n) * 10
Y <- a * X + b + eps
require(MASS)
coef(polr(bin3 ~ X, data = cbind(binY(Y), X)))

##      X 
## -2.185

coef(polr(bin5 ~ X, data = cbind(binY(Y), X)))

##      X 
## -1.852

coef(polr(bin7 ~ X, data = cbind(binY(Y), X)))

##      X 
## -1.924

The estimated coefficients are lower than the true value.

1.2

beta3 <- NULL
beta5 <- NULL
beta7 <- NULL
for (i in 1:500) {
    n <- 200
    a <- -1  #Choose anything I want?
    b <- 5  #Choose anything I want?
    eps <- rnorm(n)
    X <- runif(n) * 10
    Y <- a * X + b + eps
    data <- cbind(binY(Y), X)
    three <- polr(bin3 ~ X, data = data)
    five <- polr(bin5 ~ X, data = data)
    seven <- polr(bin7 ~ X, data = data)
    beta3 <- c(beta3, summary(three)$coefficients[1, 2])
    beta5 <- c(beta5, summary(five)$coefficients[1, 2])
    beta7 <- c(beta7, summary(seven)$coefficients[1, 2])
}
summary(beta3)

##    Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max. 
##   0.146   0.193   0.215   0.220   0.242   0.410

summary(beta5)

##    Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max. 
##   0.122   0.147   0.157   0.159   0.169   0.229

summary(beta7)

##    Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max. 
##   0.108   0.130   0.138   0.139   0.145   0.176

The estimated standard errors decrease as we increase the number of bins for Y.

2.1

The loglinear model should include the AS term because we are treating these as explanatory variables.

2.2

infants <- read.table("http://www.hofroe.net/stat557/data/infants.txt", sep = "\t", 
    header = T)
four_way <- glm(formula = Count ~ .^4, family = poisson(link = log), data = infants)
three_way <- glm(formula = Count ~ .^3, family = poisson(link = log), data = infants)
two_way <- glm(formula = Count ~ .^2, family = poisson(link = log), data = infants)
one_way <- glm(formula = Count ~ (Smoking + Age)^2 + Gestation + Survival, family = poisson(link = log), 
    data = infants)
anova(one_way, two_way, test = "Chisq")

## Analysis of Deviance Table
## 
## Model 1: Count ~ (Smoking + Age)^2 + Gestation + Survival
## Model 2: Count ~ (Age + Smoking + Gestation + Survival)^2
##   Resid. Df Resid. Dev Df Deviance Pr(>Chi)    
## 1        10        360                         
## 2         5          2  5      358   <2e-16 ***
## ---
## Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

There is a significant improvement going from the one_way to the two_way model. Next, we compare the model with all two-way interactions, to the model with all three-way interactions (to see if there is significant improvement).

anova(two_way, three_way, test = "Chisq")

## Analysis of Deviance Table
## 
## Model 1: Count ~ (Age + Smoking + Gestation + Survival)^2
## Model 2: Count ~ (Age + Smoking + Gestation + Survival)^3
##   Resid. Df Resid. Dev Df Deviance Pr(>Chi)
## 1         5      1.723                     
## 2         1      0.359  4     1.36     0.85

Clearly, adding all the three-way interactions doesn't improve our model fit enough to justify a model of order 3. In fact, the improvement is not significant at any reasonable level. Thus, we will search for the “best” model of second order. In order to do this, throw any coefficients that are insignificant at the 0.1 level in the two_way model.

p <- summary(two_way)$coefficients[, 4]  #p-values for coefs
names(p[as.numeric(p) < 0.1])

## [1] "(Intercept)"                "Age>= 30"                  
## [3] "Smoking>= 5"                "Gestation> 260"            
## [5] "SurvivalYes"                "Age>= 30:Smoking>= 5"      
## [7] "Age>= 30:Gestation> 260"    "Age>= 30:SurvivalYes"      
## [9] "Gestation> 260:SurvivalYes"

best_model <- glm(formula = Count ~ Age + Smoking + Gestation + Survival + Age:Smoking + 
    Age:Gestation + Age:Survival + Gestation:Survival, family = poisson(link = log), 
    data = infants)
anova(one_way, best_model, test = "Chisq")

## Analysis of Deviance Table
## 
## Model 1: Count ~ (Smoking + Age)^2 + Gestation + Survival
## Model 2: Count ~ Age + Smoking + Gestation + Survival + Age:Smoking + 
##     Age:Gestation + Age:Survival + Gestation:Survival
##   Resid. Df Resid. Dev Df Deviance Pr(>Chi)    
## 1        10        360                         
## 2         7          5  3      355   <2e-16 ***
## ---
## Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

anova(best_model, two_way, test = "Chisq")

## Analysis of Deviance Table
## 
## Model 1: Count ~ Age + Smoking + Gestation + Survival + Age:Smoking + 
##     Age:Gestation + Age:Survival + Gestation:Survival
## Model 2: Count ~ (Age + Smoking + Gestation + Survival)^2
##   Resid. Df Resid. Dev Df Deviance Pr(>Chi)
## 1         7       4.79                     
## 2         5       1.72  2     3.07     0.22

As expected, there is a significant improvement moving from the one_way model to the best_model. However, the two_way model is not significantly better than the best_model.

2.3

backward <- step(four_way, direction = "backward")

## Start:  AIC=124
## Count ~ (Age + Smoking + Gestation + Survival)^4
## 
##                                  Df Deviance AIC

## <none>                                 0.000 124
##

The end result of backward selection is very similar to the model choosen in 2.1. That is, the model choosen by backward selection is the same as the best_model in 2.1, with the Smoking:Survival interation included.

upper <- formula(four_way)
forward <- step(one_way, scope = list(upper = upper), direction = "forward")

## Start:  AIC=464.1

The end result of backward selection is very similar to the model choosen in 2.1. That is, the model choosen by forward selection is the same as the best_model in 2.1, with the Smoking:Survival interation included.
